Credit: NASA Worldview. \label{AtmosphericRiver

Landsat-5 acquired this image on October 5, 2011. Vibrant green filaments stretch out from the northern shore. Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory reports the bloom is primarily microcystis aeruginosa, a toxic algae to mammals. Several days of calm winds and warm temperatures allowed algae to accumulate on the surface. \label{LakeErieHAB

The threat posed by climate change to coral reefs is significant. Human development and population growth in coastal areas alter the landscape, increasing land-based pollution and endangering coral reefs. Based on infographics from the NOAA National Ocean Service. \label{CoralReefs

The total number of lightning strikes accumulated from 2008 to 2017, represented as annual strokes per square kilometer on a 0.1° x 0.1° grid. The data comes from the World Wide Lightning Location Network, and the map is an upgrade of the 0.25° x 0.25° global climatology published by Virts et al. [2013]. \label{lightning
Schematic representation some of the key primary and secondary air pollutants and some of their sources. \label{Pollutants

The stratospheric ozone hole forms within the polar vortex. The upper panel shows a visualization of the vortex surrounded by the  polar jet stream. The lower panels show example maps of the total ozone hole, potential vorticity (PV) and temperature where the vortex is clearly evident in the ozone amount, PV and temperature. \label{OzoneHole
The average size of the ozone hole in millions of square km for the southern hemisphere spring (September 7 -- October 13) from 1979 -- 2021. Courtesy of NASA Earth Observatory.\label{SizeOfOzoneHole
Key scientists involved in explaining the formation of the ozone hole. \label{OzoneScientists

From gaseous precursors, sulfate (H$_2$SO$_4$) aerosols are formed in the atmosphere by chemical reactions. There exists a layer of sulfate aerosols in the lower stratosphere ($\approx$ 20 km). Sulfur dioxide (SO$_2$) from anthropogenic sources and volcanoes, and dimethyl sulfide (DMS) from biogenic sources, especially marine plankton, are the two main sulfate precursors. After the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines in 1991, SO$_2$ was injected directly into the stratosphere, enhancing the sulfate aerosol layer and causing a cooling in the  two years following the eruption.  \label{SulfateAerosols
Arid regions can be significant sources of aoelian (wind blown) dust.  \label{Aeolian

The upper panel shows the movement of dust from the Sahara to the Amazon basin as seen from space by NASA CALIPSO. The lower panel shows smoke from southern California fires seen from space. \label{DustFireFromSpace
Acid rain is caused by emissions of sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxide, which react with the water molecules in the atmosphere to produce acids.  \label{AcidRain

Approximate annual life cycle of common ragweed across the United States. In most places ragweed flowers from August to end of October and the seeds produced stay dormant until they germinate in March.

The left panel depicts, by nation, where the majority of the world's CO$_2$ emissions originate, using the most recent data from the Global Carbon Atlas. The right-hand panel displays greenhouse gas emissions by industry sector. The four broad categories that account for the majority of global greenhouse gas emissions are energy, agriculture, industry, and waste. Our energy consumption accounts for roughly three-quarters of total greenhouse gas emissions. \label{global-emissions-4

There are various biotic and abiotic stresses that plants face, both above and below ground. There are biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOCs) generated by plant leaves, roots, and flowers. These compounds may be a constitutive characteristic, or they may be induced by biotic and abiotic stresses \citep{Loreto2014
